text: today on x cast thousands of Somali
refugees arrived in Kenya seeking food
water and medical assistance in Amman
Jordan riot police beat protesters and
journalists to break up peaceful
demonstrations and the United States
formally recognizes the opposition
leaders in Libya as the country's
legitimate government Here I am standing
at the gates of the Dobb refugee camp in
Kenya and the people around me have
walked literally weeks to get here
recently there's been a horrible drought
and many people here have come because
they've run out of food and water in
Somalia aid workers are saying that this
is the worst drought they've seen for 60
years and more than a thousand people
per day come right here for help some of
them have been attacked by militias
along the route others have seen their
children die right in front of them
there's very little rain in this part of
Africa right now and as a result animals
are dying and many people here are
pastoralists and once all their cows and
goats and camels die they have nothing
to survive on but life in these camps is
not easy it's very humiliating and
humanizing for people to come here
they're essentially warehouse they're
fingerprinted their photograph they're
given a number a little card for food
further for their rations and then
they're told to go out and live in the
bush but because the camps were
originally designed for 90,000 people
we're now creeping to a 380,000 people
the predictions continue up to maybe
even five hundred thousand in the next
few months so what we're seeing is that
there's no there's no place for people
to live and so they're they're squatting
ultimately on the outskirts of the camp
the United Nations recently built a new
camp called fo to to house more refugees
it can it can house something like 30 or
40,000 people but the Kenyan government
does not want them to open it because
they're afraid that the refugees will
come here and they'll never leave aid
workers predict the situation is going
to get worse that a thousand people are
going to continue to arrive here every
day and the numbers are going to swell
to over a half a million soon in a rare
show of force in Jordan police officers
beat protesters to disrupt
demonstrations dozens of riot police
officers broke up a peaceful protest in
Amman Jordan today the protests started
after Friday prayers when the protesters
reached a square where they were
planning to hold the sit-in dozens of
police officers charged into their
gathering they beat several protesters
with wooden Club
several journalists who were covering
the protest including myself were also
eaten the journalists were given bright
orange vests at the beginning of the
protest to distinguish them from the
protesters when we came there weren't
any orange vests available so we went to
the protest without them I was trying to
film some of the clashes with my cell
phone camera shows about happy the
officers told me to stop filming I told
them I was a journalist and then the
officers started to hit me with the
wooden clubs the protests in Jordan have
been going on for months now so they
occur every Friday since January they
haven't been as large or as intense as
elsewhere in the Arab world but they
have continued today represented one of
the few times that the the protests have
resulted in violence the protesters are
at a moment when they're trying to
figure out how to move forward because
these protests though they occur every
Friday they seem to be fairly limited in
scope they go on for a couple of hours
and then they end it's not clear why the
protests resulted in violence this time
around today they said they would hold a
sit-in which is illegal that marked a
different tactic by them at the same
time the police response was fairly
overwhelming seemed to reflect the
government fears did the protest
movement will grow though the numbers of
protesters not risen dramatically the
persistence of the protests suggest that
the complaints are not going away
anytime soon
at a meeting in Istanbul the united
states joined more than 30 nations in
formally recognizing the rebel
leadership in Libya as the country's
legitimate government this is Steven
Erlanger of the New York Times reporting
from Paris today's decision to recognize
Libya's main opposition group which is
called the National Transitional Council
has the legitimate governing authority
in Libya means that the rebels should be
able to have much faster access to
millions of dollars in Libyan assets
that have been seized from the Qaddafi
regime by on Western government it's
also likely to mean that they have more
opportunity to buy weapons and even to
buy oil there's much discussion in the
west of how to make this transition
happen and end the war it is very
expensive the French have been leading
the conversation but not everyone agrees
today decision is designed to increase
the political pressure on Nomar Qaddafi
to leave but parallel to that is a new
thinking perhaps on the part of the
countries fighting him that perhaps they
could live with Qaddafi remaining inside
Libya's so long as he gives up all
authority that discussion which is
controversial among some members of the
coalition including the Italians who
oppose it is a reflection of the
difficulty of driving Qaddafi out of our
inside Tripoli and now after so many
days of bombing it's still not clear
that the people inside Tripoli are going
to stand up and pull Qaddafi down
you
